content.description: There's a sit and a stand.  The stand goes at V3, the sit at V4, although in my opinion the sit isn't all that difficult.  The problem itself is a little contrived, as the giant jug out left is off.  Apparently you have to stay near the arete.  All that being said, it's a fun problem with some interesting balance.  Try it.
content.protection: A few pads will make you feel best.  There's some weird body tension that makes it feel like if you blow the crux you'll be spit off in the other direction
content.location: In the warm-up area.  The obvious arete on the scoop boulder

content.description: Sit start down & left on jug. Go for small holds out on the ceiling & use the arête to top out.
content.location: Located just left of Mexican hat.

content.description: Climb the face starting on large footholds to an undercling overlap, then reach through a thin section to the lip of the boulder and top out.  This is a nice beginner problem.  Once established on the face, a bit of thought is required to reach the lip from the prominent down-sloping overlap.
content.protection: One pad is adequate and perhaps a spotter.
content.location: The face to the left of the prow.  This is on the left of the two Twin Soldiers boulders.

content.description: Climb the obvious scooping face however you'd like. shares a boulder with Ballarete and Karmic Power,
content.protection: a pad or two. Topout is scary for new folks
content.location: Warm-up area

content.description: If this were all one block i feel like it'd be better, still pretty cool though.  Sit start on the low block then use it and whatever else you can find to work your way toward the boulder's pinnacle. If V1 is your limit, this should be a good one to work.
content.protection: 1 pad over the death block below the topout should do.
content.location: Between the warm-up area and breadloaf.

content.description: Royale With Cheese is named after a scene in the cult classic Pulp Fiction, and climbs much like the movie feels-insecure, ballsy and dangerous.  Grab the sloping dirty break midway out the roof in the burger shaped boulder, pull onto the rock above a chasm where the ground slopes away downhill beneath you, and dyno high up to the sloping lip.  Grab what you can up top and try to top out and mantel onto the burger bun.  This climb is more scary than it is difficult, but it is still hard.  This burger has some spice to it, you ordered jalapenos on your meal!  This problem was a project until 2005 if I recall correctly.
content.protection: Multiple pads and spotters.  The landing is one spot in between large boulders.  It is best to jump rather than fall on this one.
content.location: Royale With Cheese is the tall roof climb on the prominent roof between the Twin Soldiers boulder and the Upstream Arete boulder.  You can't miss it.

content.description: Classic warm up in the warm up area.  Tall, slabby, with good holds the whole way.  Very enjoyable
content.location: First boulder you encounter when you walk in

content.description: jump past holds on the scoop (Vo) and grab jug rail and top out.
content.location: warmup area scoop boulder

content.description: Slopey power test piece.  Stand start on two thin slots with a good little left foot.  Make a long move up and a bit left to a OK sloper.  Edge on some bad feet out right to find the next, bad sloper at the lip for your right.  Rock up and fire for a jug finish.
content.location: 10' Right of Karmic Power.  When climbing this problem you will not feel like you are climbing on the arete.

content.description: Climb the easy, chossy face from a sit start and top out.
content.location: Left of the chossy looking roof at the top of the hill on the Mexican Hat boulder.  This boulder is the next one downstream from the Twin Soldiers.

content.description: This is the right line on the left Twin Soldier boulder.  It is right of Private Slabby.  Stand start on obvious holds, or with hands lower if you prefer.  Make nice moves on consistently large holds through the elephant skin textured rock to a very incut rail ten feet up.  One more reach leads to a fantastic jug top out.
content.location: Left Twin Soldier boulder.  This is the obvious tall face right of prominent arete.

content.description: Lovely faint left facing flake, a few feet left of The Scoop with sticky footholds.  It is possible to top out the same as that problem or a bit more independently if you so desire.
content.protection: A pad is not required as these problems are so easy.
content.location: The 6 inch left facing flake on the left side of the easy slab on the Upstream Arete boulder.

content.description: Climb the left blunt arete of the Upstream Arete Boulder using large holds at perhaps 5.6.
content.protection: One pad for beginners.  Otherwise pads are not necessary.
content.location: The leftmost arete of the Upstream Arete boulder.  It is left of The Scoop slab, and left of the faint flake (named LOC Up).

content.description: On the steep face right of Balarete is a line of decent but widely spaced holds that is very popular.  The arete is off for hands and feet.  This is an independent line.  Start as low as you can on a sidepull/gaston, crouched or standing and a left hand crimp.  Reach up with the right into the unique seam for a perfect half pad crimp.  Get the feet up and make a big deadpoint to the obvious one pad 4 finger flake.  The left hand probably travels 5 feet to reach this hold and is the crux.  The top out is relatively secure.
content.location: Steep face 5 feet right of Balarete on the Upstream Arete boulder.

content.description: Start standing at the arete and top out to the right.  Great problem.
content.location: At the far end of the warm up area, you'll know this problem when you see it, thanks to the glassy polish on a small section of the rock

content.description:
Stand start with two good underclings. Move up the arete choosing from a variety of holds and body positions. Get to the good holds near the top, and top-out with a heel. There are a ton of ways to do this problem, and it's a good warm-up before heading to the other areas. 

  You might want to avoid trying to smear on the glassy face, because this part of the rock is not your typical diabase frictiony smear.
content.protection: A pad or two and a spotter for the top-out. Although it's not tall, you wouldn't want to fall into the woodpile at your back.
content.location: This is the arete that the trail passes just at it is leaving the Warm-up area.

content.description: Sit start under the roof on a flat ledge and pull out the roof on chossy jugs to the lip.  The lower wall and footholds are crumbly rock.
content.location: This roof faces away from the Stables entrance at the top of the hill.  It is the boulder which is stacked on top of a large and half spherical boulder that is the next one down the trail from the Twin Soldiers boulders.  It is just before the Upstream Arete boulder.

content.description:
This overlooked problem lies in the corridor between the right and left Twin Soldier boulders.  It is to the right and around the corner from the problem LT.  Lock off diagonal slots on gritty rock to an easier top section with smaller holds.  This problem has good movement.   

  A nice variation is to start around the corner to the left on LT and climb into this problem at the same grade it just adds a few moves.
content.protection: A pad if you can stuff it in the narrow corridor.  Or skip it and try to step off onto the adjacent boulder if you are about to fall.  You will probably want a spot for this one.
content.location: On the left Twin Soldier boulder in the corridor between the right and left Twin Soldiers.  Right of the tall face climb called LT.

content.description: Easy slab climb on right most side of boulder
content.location: slopping boulder to climbers left of Private Slabby

content.description: Ride the prominent prow to the top that is on the left of the two Twin Soldiers boulders.  Climb up the overlaps with underclings and sloping footholds.
content.location: The prow on the left Twin Soldiers boulder.

content.description: The warm-up area is the first cluster of boulders you come to when you arrive at GS. Problems here range from easy to hard, but an abundance of easier lines combined with its location make this the perfect place to warm up.
